is just a number: How older adults view healthy aging"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Healthy aging: What it means to older adults"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The results of a survey from the McKinsey Health Institute shed light on the health perceptions and priorities of people aged 55 and older."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"A new 21-country survey from the McKinsey Health Institute sheds light on the perceptions and priorities of older adults when it comes to healthy aging."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-05-22T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]] [[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen someone contemplates growing older, \u003c/strong\u003eit\u0026rsquo;s likely with a wish for physical and financial independence, joyful and engaging activities, and closeness with loved ones. Whether by playing pickleball or mah-jongg, working a part-time job, or running after grandchildren (or all of the above), the big question is how every older adult, no matter their country or socioeconomic status, can manifest what matters to them.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar author]]\n\u003cp\u003eA new McKinsey Health Institute (MHI) survey of more than 21,000 older adults (defined as those aged 55 and older) across 21 countries finds that respondents largely agree about the importance of having purpose, managing stress, enjoying meaningful connections with others, and preserving independence.[[Footnote 1]] Consistent with external literature, and building on MHI\u0026rsquo;s previous work in this area, the analysis examined the intersection of many of those factors with respondents\u0026rsquo; subjective, or perceived, health and well-being across the dimensions of mental, physical, social, and spiritual health (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Methodology\u0026rdquo;).[[Footnote 2]]\n\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eAmong the results, unsurprisingly, is that older adults who have financial stability\u0026mdash;no matter their country\u0026mdash;are more likely than their peers to be able to adhere to healthy habits, including those that boost cognitive health.[[Footnote 3]] And contrary to the perception that older adults are tech laggards compared with their younger peers, the results find widespread technology adoption, especially in smartphone use, among the older adult population.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut on other topics, including how respondents perceive their health across the four dimensions, how they want to engage in society, and how they view the best ways to stay healthy, responses vary widely. In particular, respondents in high-income economies (HIEs) aren\u0026rsquo;t necessarily thriving more than their counterparts in upper-middle-income economies (UMIEs) and in low- and middle-income economies (LMIEs) are. For example, almost 20 percent of respondents in HIEs say they would like to work in their old age but aren\u0026rsquo;t currently doing so. Respondents living in HIEs also describe substantially lower levels of societal participation[[Footnote 4]] compared with their counterparts in other countries.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn the insights that follow, we share findings around mental, physical, social, and spiritual health and what a healthy lifespan can mean in a world that is growing older. They build on MHI\u0026rsquo;s previous work on \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/living-longer-in-better-health-six-shifts-needed-for-healthy-aging\"\u003esix shifts needed for healthy aging\u003c/a\u003e, with the goal of reenvisioning perceptions of aging around capacity rather than chronological age.[[Footnote 5]] They also support MHI\u0026rsquo;s assertion that \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/the-secret-to-great-health-escaping-the-healthcare-matrix\"\u003eempowering individuals in optimizing health\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;doesn\u0026rsquo;t undermine the roles of systems, institutions, countries, or cities.[[Footnote 6]] It\u0026rsquo;s our hope that every stakeholder, from employers to local governments to healthcare providers, can see what older adults want, evaluate what\u0026rsquo;s possible, and feel motivated to be a part of wide-scale aging transformation.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n[[StoryContainer 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAging well isn\u0026rsquo;t only possible: it\u0026rsquo;s attainable. But to make this a reality for a rapidly aging population, global stakeholders should consider not only how to boost the number of years in a life but also how to enable healthy life in those years. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome of this starts with reexamining assumptions. MHI\u0026rsquo;s previous research found that many older adults report good overall health as they age, even as their physical health declines.[[Footnote 7]] The current survey results support that research. Even among those facing the greatest disease burden, up to 46 percent report good overall health (exhibit).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n[[Sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eAnd when surveyed older adults cite lower physical-health scores, it\u0026rsquo;s notable that the rates of the other dimensions (mental, social, and spiritual) decline less rapidly\u0026mdash;or even rise, in some countries\u0026mdash;with older age. For example, in Japan, those aged 65 to 79 report the highest mental-, physical-, social-, and spiritual-health scores. One explanation for this could be that the other dimensions act as a buffer, protecting or mitigating the decline of people\u0026rsquo;s perception of their overall health despite a decline in their physical capabilities. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe extent to which other aspects of health could compensate for the decline in physical health, and balance people\u0026rsquo;s view of their overall health, is a topic for further research. As we consider actions to add life to years, part of any solution will need to focus on what drives people to take action to stay in good health. Purpose and meaningful connections with others are critical contributors to good health, as our research indicates. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd the underlying reasons for creating those connections and the definition of purpose vary. For example, our research on societal participation highlights the point that many older adults engage in activities for a variety of reasons, from staying healthy to being connected to their communities and, for some, pursuing financial gain. The motivations are multifaceted, but providing opportunities to fulfil those motivations must be a critical priority for societies. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eToo often, society and individuals accept health declines as inevitable\u0026mdash;the passing of time leading to physical deterioration. An important objective for many societies could be to ask \u0026ldquo;What would it take for more than half of people aged 80 and older to report good health over the next decade? What would it take to expand what it means to be in good health at ages 60, 70, 80, 90, and beyond?\u0026rdquo; For example, in forthcoming work, MHI will explore how a healthy city framework ties into older adults\u0026rsquo; abilities to stay active, access care, and keep connected.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHealthy aging also starts with individual actions, such as a person following behaviors proven to improve health, supported by an environment that makes them accessible to all. It\u0026rsquo;s a lifelong journey, and it\u0026rsquo;s never too late to set out on the path to becoming well aged.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you would like to learn more about the McKinsey Health Institute 2023 Global Healthy Aging Survey and the additional data and insights MHI has from the survey, please submit an inquiry via the \u003ca href=\"/mhi/contact-us\"\u003eMHI \u0026ldquo;contact us\u0026rdquo; form\u003c/a\u003e. The McKinsey Health Institute, as a non-profit-generating entity of McKinsey, is creating avenues for further research that can catalyze action.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":true},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":{"name":"McKinsey Health Institute","displayName":"McKinsey Health Institute","title":{"value":"McKinsey Health Institute"},"relatedlinks":{"url":"/mhi/overview"},"landinglinks":{"jsonValue":{"value":[]}}}},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-05-22T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe online survey was in the field from late December 2022 to February 2023 and garnered responses from more than 21,000 participants aged 55 and older across 21 countries.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMartin Dewhurst, Katherine Linzer, Madeline Maud, and Christoph Sandler, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/living-longer-in-better-health-six-shifts-needed-for-healthy-aging\"\u003eLiving longer in better health: Six shifts needed for healthy aging\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTo gain a better understanding \u003c/strong\u003eof the health perceptions, preferences, and activities of older adults (those aged 55 and older) around the world, the McKinsey Health Institute conducted an internet-based survey between late December 2022 and February 2023, collecting information on about 1,000 older adults per country. For the participants unable to fill out the survey because of medical conditions or lack of internet access, we collected responses from a spouse, child, or child-in-law. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWithin each country, we applied quotas and respondent weights to ensure that the final sample was representative for the entire country with respect to age, gender, and proportions of urban and rural location and tertiary education. We also used weights within each country to balance the sample, as much as possible, on respondents\u0026rsquo; self-reported health status. This design was to ensure that results in one country on some measures don\u0026rsquo;t look better than those from another solely because a higher proportion of their respondents report health substantially above the average for their age cohort.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eConsiderations for cross-generational surveys\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe asked about each participant\u0026rsquo;s attitudes and behaviors only at the time of the survey. Therefore, when differences in average answers between age cohorts exist, we can\u0026rsquo;t determine how much they result from different generations thinking differently versus people getting older and their preferences changing. It\u0026rsquo;s possible that younger cohorts will eventually think and behave like older cohorts once they reach the same age.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eConsiderations for surveys conducted online\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe survey was conducted online. Without proper guardrails, the survey would have been affected by substantial nonresponse bias, because individuals without reliable internet access couldn\u0026rsquo;t have been part of the sample. This is why we asked spouses, children, and children-in-law to answer on behalf of participants without reliable internet access. We used the best information available to decide on the proportions of responses to come directly from participants and from somebody answering on behalf of an older adult. It is possible, however, that we have slightly under- or overcorrected. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eConsiderations for cross-country surveys\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSubstantial cultural differences are known to exist across countries, and they can affect how respondents interpret survey questions and answers, how they use the scales, how likely they are to agree with survey questions, and how likely they are to answer truthfully. For example, past McKinsey analysis has shown that, in general, survey respondents in India have a higher propensity to agree and to agree strongly with survey statements than respondents in most other countries do. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough we relied on cultural experts to safeguard equivalence of meaning during translation across languages, some observed differences across countries may still be induced in the process. Country differences were computed as differences among country averages. Unless specified, we analyzed by taking a simple average across countries within a country income archetype and then took the simple average across archetypes in order to get an overall average.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Methodology"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"2"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNo one wants to feel alone. \u003c/strong\u003eConsistent with existing research on social isolation\u0026rsquo;s harm,[[Footnote 1]]\u0026nbsp; our analysis of responses from older adults finds that isolation is a wide-ranging problem. Globally, 10 to 20 percent of respondents report feeling isolated. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdditionally, we find that more income doesn\u0026rsquo;t necessarily help in this area. While an average of 12 percent of respondents in low- and middle-income economies report isolation, the share jumps to 19 percent in high-income economies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat potentially helps is when older adults can participate in society. In the survey, higher societal-participation[[Footnote 2]] rates correlate to decreased isolation rates: by one-third in upper-middle-income economies and up to one-half in low- and middle-income economies. How much adults benefit from the activities varies by country, potentially reflecting different structures for societal participation and perceptions of what isolation means to an individual (exhibit).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn two countries represented in the survey, India and the United States, jumping into societal activities seems to have a particularly large impact. The reported isolation rate is 8 percent for respondents in India participating in two or more activities, increasing to 33 percent for those who don\u0026rsquo;t participate in any activities. In the United States, the increase is from 9 to 25 percent. Comparatively, respondents in the United Kingdom appear to benefit less from societal participation. For UK respondents reporting no participation in social activities, the isolation rate is 19 percent, which drops minimally for those who report participation in two or more activities. \u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Isolation is complex"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eJohn T. Cacioppo and Stephanie Cacioppo, \u0026ldquo;Older adults reporting social isolation or loneliness show poorer cognitive function 4 years later,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eEvidence-Based Nursing\u003c/em\u003e, April 2014, Volume 17, Number 2.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBased on extensive literature review, we define \u0026ldquo;societal participation\u0026rdquo; as participating in at least one of the following activities: working, volunteering, pursuing education, and being active in community programs.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"3"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood news \u003c/strong\u003efor those planning to move in with their children: as noted in previous research, older adults often benefit when they can live in intergenerational households.[[Footnote 1]] As part of our research in healthy aging, we looked at survey results for older people living intergenerationally (defined in our study as those living with their adult children). Respondents in that cohort who are retired and have low levels of care needs tend to report being in better or much better than average health across dimensions compared with those not living with their children or spouse and children. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis trend varies across economy archetypes, with the greatest benefits, especially related to physical and social health, in respondents in low- and middle-income economies (exhibit). Moderate benefit is seen across all four health dimensions (mental, physical, social, and spiritual) by respondents in upper-middle-income economies. For respondents in high-income economies, those living intergenerationally report very little benefit from intergenerational living. In some countries (such as the United States), stigma against intergenerational living may contribute to an observed decline in mental health.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThis research adds to an important body of evidence pointing toward the benefits of older people living with family, especially after retirement. Coupled with the trend away from extended- or nuclear-family living, this evidence suggests an opportunity to create intentional, age-inclusive communities where older adults can interact with younger generations\u0026mdash;whether family or otherwise\u0026mdash;in their daily lives.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Living intergenerationally might benefit one’s health"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFaizan Bhatia and Raiya Suleman, \u0026ldquo;Intergenerational housing as a model for improving older-adult health,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eBC Medical Journal\u003c/em\u003e, May 2021, Volume 63, Number 4. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}}]},"globalsidebar":{"results":[]},"video":{"results":[]},"scrollycontainer":{"results":[]},"bespokeinteractive":{"results":[]},"storycontainer":{"results":[{"id":"FEBA7A39887B481082D0D554E1D533AA","mediaID":{"value":"1"},"collapseTopSpace":{"boolValue":false},"collapseBottomSpace":{"boolValue":false},"desktopTextColumnWidth":{"targetItem":null},"children":{"results":[{"id":"4A0297A5F7A94F1D94DC0FC54EF17DC4","name":"Exhibit 1","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"A dozen factors emerge as most closely associated with perceived health"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eMHI asked survey participants about 53 factors, ranging from societal participation to exercise, to assess what matters most to older adults and how those individual factors may affect health. The analysis reveals that purpose, stress, physical activity, lifelong learning, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-the-worlds-longest-study-of-adult-development-finds-the-key-to-happy-living\"\u003emeaningful connections with others\u003c/a\u003e, and financial security are the factors most strongly associated with respondents\u0026rsquo; overall perceived health. While there are nuanced differences by country, overall, respondents in HIEs and UMIEs emphasize stress and financial decisions, while those in LMIEs highlight the importance of exercise and sleep. These factors often tie into how respondents perceive their mental, physical, social, and spiritual health.\u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/age is just a number how older adults view healthy aging/svgz-healthyaging-ex1-vf.svgz","alt":"Having purpose, managing stress, physical activity, lifelong learning, and interacting with others matter most to overall health.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"07240B04C8EF457E9AA5DD57DBC1D884","name":"Flourish 2","template":{"name":"FlourishForStory"},"title":{"value":"Mental and spiritual health are the most favorably rated dimensions"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eOverall, survey respondents\u0026rsquo; perceived health across all four dimensions declines with age. Physical health has the sharpest drop\u0026mdash;38 percent\u0026mdash;when looking at the average response, across all countries, between the youngest and oldest cohorts. For those aged 55 to 64, mental health tends to be the most positively rated dimension. For those aged 65 and older, spiritual health becomes the most positively rated dimension. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen examining economies and whether they affect health, the picture is mixed. On average, respondents in LMIEs report better average health than those in HIEs did. Yet respondents in HIEs report an increase in health across all dimensions from about age 55 to about age 79, which may be correlated to retirement. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOf the countries represented in the survey, Australia and Japan were the only two where perceived mental, social, and spiritual health increased with age, with scores among those aged 80 and older higher than those of their counterparts aged between 55 and 64. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRespondents in China report the smallest declines in physical health, while those in Sweden report the smallest declines in mental and social health. Respondents in Egypt, Nigeria, and South Africa\u0026mdash;the African countries represented in the survey\u0026mdash;report the smallest declines in spiritual health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYet perceptions of health don\u0026rsquo;t always connect to life expectancy. \u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"flourishVisualisationID":{"value":"visualisation/13554197"},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"43DFF183142C42EEA43B519D2B3EFC31","name":"Exhibit 3","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Living longer may not mean better perceived health"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eOn average, \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/living-longer-in-better-health-six-shifts-needed-for-healthy-aging\"\u003eolder people can expect\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to have an additional 20 years of life expectancy compared with those in 1960.[[Footnote 1]] But survey respondents living in countries with higher healthy life expectancy in old age (as measured by the WHO[[Footnote 2]]) don\u0026rsquo;t necessarily report better perceived health. What\u0026rsquo;s more, \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/in-sickness-and-in-health-how-health-is-perceived-around-the-world\"\u003ethose with chronic conditions don\u0026rsquo;t necessarily report poor health\u003c/a\u003e. The report rates of perceived overall positive health status of respondents with the greatest disease burden are 27 percent, 40 percent, and 53 percent by those in HIEs, UMIEs, and LMIEs, respectively. This reaffirms that health is much more than the absence or presence of disease and consists of multiple dimensions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAcross the 21 countries represented in the survey, Japan has the highest healthy life expectancy for those in old age, but the share of Japanese respondents reporting very good or good perceived health is among the lowest. In general, a lower share of HIE respondents reports very good or good perceived health compared with other economies. The exception is in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, where respondents have relatively high perceptions of their health. \u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/age is just a number how older adults view healthy aging/svgz-healthyaging-ex3-vf2.svgz","alt":"There is dissonance between perceived health and healthy life expectancy.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eWorld Bank Open Data, World Bank, accessed on May 10, 2023. For more, see \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/living-longer-in-better-health-six-shifts-needed-for-healthy-aging\"\u003eLiving longer in better health\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; November 11, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMeasurement of \u0026ldquo;the average number of years in full health a person (usually at age 60) can expect to live based on current rates of ill-health and mortality.\u0026rdquo; Global Health Observatory, WHO, updated on December 4, 2020. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"A373BD2779B5438E8360DB3FC07CD0DE","name":"Ceros 4","template":{"name":"CerosForStory"},"title":{"value":"The factors with the greatest uplift broadly align with those identified as most important"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eIn addition to looking at the factors that respondents report as most important to their health, our analysis looked at the factors with the greatest uplift.[[Footnote 1]] We examined what would happen if everyone could achieve the same level of perceived health as those with the best reports of a specific factor. For example, managing stress has meaningful potential uplift. Among respondents aged 65 to 79, those who agree or strongly agree that they \u0026ldquo;manage their stress levels\u0026rdquo; have a 17-percentage-point uplift, on average, in their perceived overall health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFeeling respected by one\u0026rsquo;s community and feeling that one\u0026rsquo;s perspective as an older adult is valued also result in substantial uplifts, with the greatest effect seen in respondents in HIEs\u0026mdash;so much so that the difference between perceived health and life expectancy almost completely disappears. This supports the idea that reframing aging has the potential to alter how older adults perceive their own health. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt first glance, there appears to be less potential uplift for respondents in LMIEs, but the picture is more complicated. Such respondents give a higher baseline rating across most factors at the onset compared with their peers. For example, among respondents in LMIEs, a sense of purpose is largely ubiquitous. So selecting for the population subset that rates purpose most favorably invariably includes almost the entire sample, leading to little room for uplift.\u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Uplift\u0026rdquo; is defined as the net positive impact on overall health status when including only the survey participants who respond that they agree or strongly agree with the statement related to the specific factor compared with the average of all respondents. Uplifts are based on correlation, not causation. The factors that are deemed important and also result in substantive uplift are shown. Factors with insufficient sample size in numerous countries are excluded from this analysis.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"desktopID":{"value":"experience-646648b414b2d"},"desktopURL":{"value":"//view.ceros.com/mckinsey/healthyaging04"},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":"97.01"},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":"experience-646648b414b2d"},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":"97.01"},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":"//view.ceros.com/mckinsey/healthyaging04"},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false}},{"id":"EF4435A238CE4FB78B3DFE3DCCB6B421","name":"Exhibit 5","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Older adults in high-income economies are active but less engaged than their peers"},"description":{"value":"Across countries and incomes, employment is the most frequently reported societal-participation activity, followed by formal volunteering by respondents in LMIEs and community activities by respondents in HIEs and UMIEs. Most surprising: fewer than 60 percent of the respondents in HIEs report engaging in any type of societal participation. While reasons may vary, our research finds a meaningful opportunity around increasing societal participation, with up to 44 percent of older adults expressing a desire to engage in a new type of activity."},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/age is just a number how older adults view healthy aging/svgz-healthyaging-ex5-vf2.svgz","alt":"Older adults are socially active, and many want to do even more.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"9562F99C2B044FFDB898ED9C9F91CE49","name":"Exhibit 6","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Greatest perceived-health benefit is seen with volunteering and employment"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eParticipating pays off. Reports of overall health are better for survey respondents who engage in working, volunteering, education, and community activities than for those who don\u0026rsquo;t. The greatest gain is seen with volunteering (eight percentage points, on average). When looking at country and country income archetypes, results vary, but in one example, the perceived benefit of volunteering correlates to increased wealth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDeclining health can be a barrier to overall societal participation but isn\u0026rsquo;t a deal-breaker. Our data show that there is strong demand in this area even for those in less-than-ideal health. More than one-fifth of respondents in poor health report working, and the rates rise to 32 percent and 44 percent for respondents in average and good health, respectively. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere is an opportunity to both boost older adults\u0026rsquo; participation in society and benefit society overall. While it\u0026rsquo;s intuitive to connect more economic impact with employment, this analysis also indicates that older adults who volunteer, participate in community activities, or further their education are potentially more likely to report better health, reducing their healthcare costs in turn (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Isolation is complex\u0026rdquo;).\n\u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/age is just a number how older adults view healthy aging/svgz-healthyaging-ex6-vf.svgz","alt":"Societal participation aligns with better perceived health.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"6D13CBF01762447C9466F7005EEC6CDC","name":"Ceros 7","template":{"name":"CerosForStory"},"title":{"value":"Many older adults who wish to work are unable to find a job"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eWhile the desire to work tends to decline with age\u0026mdash;to 38 percent for respondents aged 80 and older, from more than two-thirds of those aged 55 to 64\u0026mdash;a sizeable share of older adults report wanting to work. When evaluating the associated economic implications, there is the potential for $5 trillion in incremental annual GDP in HIEs. Across economies, 19 to 25 percent of survey respondents want to work but aren\u0026rsquo;t doing so. They most often cite a lack of attractive opportunities and difficulty in landing jobs as their primary barriers. \u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":""},"desktopID":{"value":"experience-6466597c68553"},"desktopURL":{"value":"//view.ceros.com/mckinsey/healthyaging07"},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":"73.4"},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":"experience-6466597c68553"},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":"73.4"},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":"//view.ceros.com/mckinsey/healthyaging07"},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false}},{"id":"F2067F53BA9D454F95F1CD7ABD610206","name":"Exhibit 8","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Challenges with finding a job and attractive opportunities"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eRoughly three in ten respondents in LMIEs and HIEs cite \u0026ldquo;difficulty getting a job\u0026rdquo; as their top barrier to employment.[[Footnote 1]] Within countries, the range of respondents citing this as the top challenge is 25 (in Malaysia) to 55 percent (in Mexico).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany respondents across economies name a \u0026ldquo;lack of opportunities\u0026rdquo; as a barrier to working. However, more respondents in LMIEs than in other economies also say \u0026ldquo;not knowing where to look for jobs\u0026rdquo; is a barrier.[[Footnote 2]] Could technology help with that challenge? \u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/age is just a number how older adults view healthy aging/svgz-healthyaging-ex8-vf.svgz","alt":"Difficulty landing a job and lack of attractive opportunities are greatest barriers to employment.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor more, see \u003cem\u003eAchieving equitable healthy aging in low- and middle-income countries: The Aging Readiness \u0026amp; Competitiveness Report 4.0\u003c/em\u003e, a joint report from AARP and Economic Impact, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eA further examination on the barriers and opportunities to societal participation will be published in summer 2023. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"15E3585059F04D768ECEA70C32B2DBC9","name":"Exhibit 9","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Debunking the myth about older adults and technology"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eThe vast majority of survey respondents aged 55 to 64 use a smartphone; the percentage drops almost in half for residents aged 80 and older. When looking at countries, usage also varies widely. Three-fourths of those aged 80 and older in China have a smartphone, compared with less than one-third of that cohort in France. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile more than 40 percent of those oldest respondents say they want to use a smartphone, and 25 percent say they want to use a laptop or tablet, there is a share uninterested in using technology. Roughly one in five respondents aged 80 and over are saying no to all technology products in their life. Within countries, that share ranges from more than 40 percent (in Brazil and France) to under 10 percent in China, India, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia, and Sweden. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese differences reflect a variety of factors, from access to interest to lifelong use. Respondents say the biggest barriers to technology adoption are around cost and a lack of knowledge, with the former more important for younger cohorts and the latter more important for older cohorts. Other barriers include lack of availability, lack of trust, and poor internet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo address these issues, it\u0026rsquo;s possible that lower costs and more education could help the oldest respondents. But given how the youngest cohort of older adults is invested in technology, there will be a naturally higher penetration of use among older adults over time. In other words, stakeholders are wise to start dismantling the idea that elderly people don\u0026rsquo;t want, know how to use, or have a smartphone. \u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/age is just a number how older adults view healthy aging/svgz-healthyaging-ex9-vf.svgz","alt":"Overcoming the knowledge gap is the key to greater technology adoption.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":""},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"EBCC7ECB48AD49B3A0DC1C9C28279463","name":"Exhibit 10","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Economic inequality poses challenges to health"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eMHI also tested older-adult adherence to behaviors shown to affect either the development or the progression of dementia.[[Footnote 1]] Our research indicates that older adults need more support to follow healthy behaviors. Managing stress is the only behavior in which a majority of respondents across financial-situation cohorts report surpassing the minimum generally acceptable benchmark. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRespondents least adhere to the behavior of \u0026ldquo;taking care of one\u0026rsquo;s physical health.\u0026rdquo; Some of this could be attributed to financial situation; those who report living comfortably, with discretionary spending, are 73 percent more likely than their peers to eat healthy foods and subscribe to a balanced diet. Yet even for those who are financially stable, many are still avoiding best health practices. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBehavior dissonance isn\u0026rsquo;t a problem unique to older adults; there are fathomless actions that individuals know are good for them yet don\u0026rsquo;t do. However, the survey results are worrisome when contemplating the rising rate of cognitive decline. This ties into the need to address global poverty\u0026rsquo;s impact on healthy habits. \u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/age is just a number how older adults view healthy aging/svgz-healthyaging-ex10-vf.svgz","alt":"Economic inequality aligns with poorer adherence to healthy brain habits.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThis was based on adjusted selections from the \u0026ldquo;Dementia prevention, intervention, and care\u0026rdquo; report by the \u003cem\u003eLancet \u003c/em\u003eCommission.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"White"},"value":{"value":"-bg-white"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"7C6FA108FF9B461EA0B1700DBA68312C","name":"Exhibit 11","template":{"name":"StoryItem"},"title":{"value":"Older adults want to stay in their homes, but that’s not always possible"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eNot surprisingly, most survey respondents want to stay in their homes as they age. However, living at home isn\u0026rsquo;t without challenges for older adults. For example, those living alone may be at risk of having a sudden medical emergency without the ability to access help or a potentially life-threatening household problem (such as forgetting to turn off the stove). \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEmploying external supports (for example, a laundry service), using technology (such as remote monitoring), and embarking on home renovations (such as a ground-floor bedroom and ramps) could potentially let older adults stay in their homes longer.[[Footnote 1]] The discussions about how to plan for aging should start early, preferably in midlife (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Living intergenerationally might benefit one\u0026rsquo;s health\u0026rdquo;). \u003c/p\u003e"},"exhibitImage":{"src":"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/age is just a number how older adults view healthy aging/svgz-healthyaging-ex11-vf.svgz","alt":"Eighty percent of older adults want to live in their own home, but not all are able.","description":""},"scaleToFit":{"boolValue":false},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor more, see Michele Lerner, \u0026ldquo;More older people are opting to age in their homes. Here\u0026rsquo;s how they\u0026rsquo;re doing it,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eWashingtonian\u003c/em\u003e, March 13, 2023.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"backgroundTheme":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Gray"},"value":{"value":"-bg-lightest-grey"}}},"mediaPlacement":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Right"},"value":{"value":"is-align-right"}}},"eyebrow":{"value":""},"displayNumber":{"value":""}},{"id":"D96A768025DD40B190F912ED3CF6A860","name":"Ceros 12","template":{"name":"CerosForStory"},"title":{"value":"The desire to remain independent can be a barrier to accessing care"},"description":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eAll respondents report at least one unmet care need. Participants in UMIEs and HIEs report the desire to remain independent as the main barrier to accessing care. While that\u0026rsquo;s also a concern for those in LMIEs, they report access to care and affordability as more pressing. These trends persist across gender and age cohorts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs populations age and dependency ratios increase, health stakeholders will need to ensure not only access to care and its quality but also responsiveness of available care to older adults\u0026rsquo; desire to remain independent. This could include increasing the focus on in-home services and other community-based types of care. In this area, Norway is a lighthouse for its use of technology, such as \u003ca href=\"https://nordicwelfare.org/en/publikationer/nordic-ambient-assisted-living-welfare-technologies-for-active-and-independent-living-at-home/\"\u003ecare coordination platforms and digital-key systems\u003c/a\u003e, and Singapore is a notable example of intergenerational care tied to health.[[Footnote 1]] \u003c/p\u003e"},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor more, see
